stem: The nurse in a prenatal clinic is assessing a client at 34 weeks gestation. Based on the client's reported symptoms and the findings in the EHR, indicate which findings represent normal discomforts of pregnancy versus those that require immediate further evaluation.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
09:00: Ms. Rivera (34y/o, G1P0) presents for her 34-week prenatal visit. Client reports she has been feeling 'very heavy' and tired. 
09:15: Client states, 'I've been getting these strange tightening feelings in my stomach, but they go away when I walk. My lower back also aches at the end of the day.' 
09:30: Upon further questioning, client mentions she has had a persistent headache that 'won't go away with Tylenol' and noticed her wedding ring is suddenly too tight to remove. 
09:45: Client also reports a small amount of bright red vaginal spotting after intercourse yesterday.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Appears slightly anxious. Noted mild periorbital edema. 
Abdomen: Fundal height 34 cm. FHR 144 bpm via doppler. 
Extremities: 2+ pitting edema in bilateral ankles and feet. 1+ edema noted in bilateral hands. 
Musculoskeletal: Reports mild discomfort in the pubic symphysis area when walking.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content:
Urine Dipstick (09:15): 
- Protein: 3+ (Abnormal) 
- Glucose: Negative 
- Nitrites: Negative

rows.text: Continuous, severe headache not relieved by acetaminophen
Lower backache and pelvic pressure at the end of the day
Tightening of the abdomen that decreases with movement (Braxton-Hicks contractions)
Sudden swelling of the face and hands
Small amount of bright red vaginal bleeding

rationale.correct: Danger signs in late pregnancy include symptoms of Preeclampsia (severe headache, facial/hand edema, BP > 140/90) and potential Placenta Previa/Abruption (vaginal bleeding). Normal discomforts include postural backache and Braxton-Hicks contractions, which are irregular and typically resolve with activity changes. This client is showing signs of Preeclampsia (High BP, 3+ protein, periorbital edema, and persistent headache).
clinicalPearls: Proteinuria (3+) and severe headache in the third trimester constitute a medical emergency (Preeclampsia).
Always differentiate Braxton-Hicks from True Labor: Braxton-Hicks do NOT cause cervical change and often stop with walking.
Any vaginal bleeding in the third trimester requires a 'no vaginal exam' policy until a speculum/ultrasound rules out placenta previa.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that hand/foot edema is 'normal' for all pregnant women.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Differentiate dependent edema (ankles at night) from generalized edema (face/hands in the morning). Generalized edema is a danger sign.

mnemonic.title: Preeclampsia Signs
mnemonic.expansion: H-E-A-D: Headache, Edema (Facial), Abdominal pain (RUQ), Dazzling (Vision changes).
